title: Selective CO
Adsorption on Metal-Organic Frameworks Based on Trinuclear Cu
-Pyrazolato Complexes: An Experimental and Computational Study
abstract: Two related three-fold and eight-fold interpenetrated MOFs expand upon selective CO

Two related metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) based on trinuclear copper-pyrazolato structural building units (SBUs) connected by bipyridine linkers have been prepared and studied. A small chemical modification to the supporting pyrazolato ligands of a [Cu

]-SBU results in two vastly different (three-fold vs eight-fold interpenetrated) MOF structures. The gas sorption properties of the two MOFs have been determined experimentally in the 0 to 10 atm pressure range. Both MOFs sorb CO
, showing hysteretic sorption–desorption profiles. The hysteretic behavior is attributed to the structural flexibility of the lattices, probed by powder X-ray diffraction before and after CO
sorption. As the metal centers and hydroxy groups of the MOF surfaces are sterically hindered, the sorbed dipolar CO
molecules are attached with low sorption enthalpy to the organic groups, as determined by theoretical calculations.
text: Metal organic frameworks (MOFs) are three-dimensional (3D) porous coordination polymers (PCPs) prepared by the combination of organic linkers (bridges) and inorganic nodes.
Yaghi and O’Keeffe have compiled rational synthetic strategies for the design of MOFs, coining the term “reticular chemistry” for this approach.

In addition to single metal-atom nodes, preformed clusters, known as secondary building units (SBUs), such as polynuclear metal complexes and polyoxometallates, have been employed in the construction of MOFs.

SBUs impart their physicochemical properties onto the resulting MOFs. Owing to their amenability to structural and chemical modification, MOFs can potentially be used in a wide variety of industrial and laboratory processes.
While their functions as drug carriers,
have also been investigated, their principal proposed use is in gas storage and separation because of their tunable porosity.
is the primary anthropogenic greenhouse gas, whose current globally averaged atmospheric mole fraction is 391 ppm, approximately 140% of its preindustrial level.
Devising efficient technologies for the removal of CO
and other greenhouse gases is now recognized as an urgent priority by both governments and scientific communities. Selective removal of CO
can be accomplished by sorption based on size-discrimination: CO
has a smaller kinetic diameter (3.30 Å) than that of N
(3.46 Å). Among MOFs, the first example of preferential uptake of CO
and also Ar (kinetic diameter, 3.4 Å) has been shown in a lanthanide MOF.
Alternatively, separation can be achieved taking advantage of specific sorbent–sorbate interactions, such as chemical and/or dipole–dipole or induced dipole interactions.

), enabling it to attach preferentially to the pore surfaces of the sorbent via polar and van der Waals (vdW) interactions. As a class of materials with great chemical tunability, MOFs have been studied extensively for selective adsorption of CO
on a microporous MOF fixed bed has been reported.
MOFs that show the desirable high and selective CO

uptake possess the following distinct features: (1) accessible coordinatively unsaturated metal sites, (2) appropriate pore size and geometry, and (3) amine-, carboxyl-, or hydroxyl-functionalities on pore surfaces.
Size and functionality independent selectivity is rare and has been observed only in a few cases.
The origin of selectivity has been suggested to lie in the activation protocol: dehydration of MOF samples at different temperatures has led to different selectivities.
)], reported recently, has the highest selectivity for CO
(8:1) for a PCP without open metal sites.

selectivity is also known in MOFs, showing gating behavior at certain temperature/pressure combinations. In the absence of chemisorption and highly polar sites on the sorbent, weak vdW sorbent–sorbate interactions may be sufficient to selectively adsorb CO
and do so with low sorption enthalpy, an advantage with regard to the energy cost of desorption and sorbent recycling but with the disadvantage of low sorption capacity.
In spite of considerable progress, the full range and nature of CO
interaction modes with porous materials are still not thoroughly explored and understood.
An important class of materials that often show selectivity is interpenetrated frameworks.
Temperature, pressure, ligand geometry, and solvation tend to alter the degree of interpenetration and porosity.

For example, a three-fold interpenetrated framework based on bipy-like pillars and dicarboxylate linkers, which also show selectivity, hysteresis, and dynamic behavior upon adsorption has been reported.
A recent example of partially interpenetrated framework, the second interpenetrated net having a partial occupancy, shows CO
selectivity at low pressure and hysteresis at high pressure.

In summary, a small chemical modification to the [Cu

]-SBU, namely the introduction of a Cl atom at the four-position of the bridging pyrazolato ligands, has resulted in major structural differences between the two MOFs. As the dimensions of the two SBUs vary marginally, the shift from eight-fold to three-fold interpenetration is tentatively attributed to their different charge distributions and interactions between local dipoles. With regard to their gas sorption properties, both
behave qualitatively in a similar manner (i.e., both sorb CO
), even though their porosities differ greatly. However, theoretical study of CO

Metal-organic frameworks: a new class of porous materials
Rowsell, Jesse L. C.; Yaghi, Omar M.

A review of the synthesis, structure, and properties of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) is presented, highlighting the important advances in their research over the past decade.  This new class of porous materials is attracting attention due to demonstrations of their large pore sizes, high apparent surface areas, selective uptake of small mols., and optical or magnetic responses to the inclusion of guests.  More importantly, their synthesis from mol. building blocks holds the potential for directed tailoring of these properties.
Design of MOFs and intellectual content in reticular chemistry: a personal view

A review.  This article gives a personal perspective on the ideas leading to the development of reticular chem.  The feasibility of achieving targeted materials with predetd. metrics and functionality by designed synthesis is defended.
Tranchemontagne, David J.; Ni, Zheng; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.

A review.  Metal-org. polyhedra (MOPs), are discrete metal-org. mol. assemblies.  They are useful as host mols. that can provide tailorable internal vol. in terms of metrics, functionality, and active metal sites.  As a result, these materials are potentially useful for a variety of applications such as highly selective guest inclusion and gas storage, and as nanoscale reaction vessels.  This review identifies the nine most important polyhedra, and describes the design principles for the five polyhedra most likely to result from the assembly of secondary building units, and provides examples of these shapes that are known as metal-org. crystals.
Reticular synthesis and the design of new materials
Yaghi, Omar M.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Ockwig, Nathan W.; Chae, Hee K.; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Kim, Jaheon

A review.  The long-standing challenge of designing and constructing new cryst. solid-state materials from mol. building blocks is just beginning to be addressed with success.  A conceptual approach that requires the use of secondary building units to direct the assembly of ordered frameworks epitomizes this process: the authors call this approach reticular synthesis.  This chem. has yielded materials designed to have predetd. structures, compns. and properties.  In particular, highly porous frameworks held together by strong metal-O-C bonds and with exceptionally large surface area and capacity for gas storage were prepd. and their pore metrics systematically varied and functionalized.
There is no corresponding record for this reference.
Czaja, Alexander U.; Trukhan, Natalia; Muller, Ulrich

A review.  New materials are prerequisite for major breakthrough applications affecting the daily life, and therefore are pivotal for the chem. industry.  Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) constitute an emerging class of materials useful in gas storage, gas purifn., and sepn. applications as well as heterogeneous catalysis.  They not only offer higher surface areas and the potential for enhanced activity than currently used materials like base metal oxides, but also provide shape/size selectivity which is important both for sepns. and catalysis.  In this crit. review an overview of the potential applications of MOFs in the chem. industry is presented.  Furthermore, the synthesis and characterization of the materials are briefly discussed from the industrial perspective.
Horcajada, Patricia; Gref, Ruxandra; Baati, Tarek; Allan, Phoebe K.; Maurin, Guillaume; Couvreur, Patrick; Ferey, Gerard; Morris, Russell E.; Serre, Christian
A review.  Coordination polymers or MOFs (metal-org. frameworks) as porous solids for biomedical are reviewed.
Mixed-valence Li/Fe-based metal-organic frameworks with both reversible redox and sorption properties
Ferey, Gerard; Millange, Franck; Morcrette, Mathieu; Serrem, Christian; Doublet, Marie-Liesse; Grenech, Jean-Marc; Tarascon, Jean-Marie

The prepn. and use of use of mixed-valence metal-org. frameworks as rechargeable intercalation cathodes for Li batteries were studied.  The gravimetric (75 mA-h/g) and volumetric (140 mA-h/L) electrochem. capacities of [FeIII(OH)(O2CC6H4CO2)] for Li are modest, owing to the limited no. of inserted Li atoms per formula unit (0.6) and the low d. of the material (1.7 g/cm3), such values may be improved by using structures with other transition metals and/or ligands.  The system presented here is a preliminary result, but note that the amt. of inserted Li into these phases increases as a function of the fluorine content.
Lee, Jeong Yong; Farha, Omar K.; Roberts, John; Scheidt, Karl A.; Nguyen, Son Binh T.; Hupp, Joseph T.

A review; a crit. review of the emerging field of MOF-based catalysis is presented.  Discussed are examples of: (a) opportunistic catalysis with metal nodes, (b) designed catalysis with framework nodes, (c) catalysis by homogeneous catalysts incorporated as framework struts, (d) catalysis by MOF-encapsulated mol. species, (e) catalysis by metal-free org. struts or cavity modifiers, and (f) catalysis by MOF-encapsulated clusters.
Allendorf, M. D.; Bauer, C. A.; Bhakta, R. K.; Houk, R. J. T.

A review; metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) display a wide range of luminescent behaviors resulting from the multifaceted nature of their structure.  In this crit. review we discuss the origins of MOF luminosity, which include the linker, the coordinated metal ions, antenna effects, excimer and exciplex formation, and guest mols.  The literature describing these effects is comprehensively surveyed, including a categorization of each report according to the type of luminescence obsd.  Finally, we discuss potential applications of luminescent MOFs.  This review will be of interest to researchers and synthetic chemists attempting to design luminescent MOFs, and those engaged in the extension of MOFs to applications such as chem., biol., and radiation detection, medical imaging, and electro-optical devices.
Li, Jian-Rong; Sculley, Julian; Zhou, Hong-Cai

A review.  This article reviews the metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), a new class of porous solid materials.  Their performances for applications in sepns. and purifications is attracting intense interest of researchers working in the fields of chem., chem. engineering, materials science, and others.  Despite being in its infancy, the research progress in this subject has already shown that MOFs are promising for sepn. applications.
There is no corresponding record for this reference.
Porous lanthanide-organic frameworks: synthesis, characterization, and unprecedented gas adsorption properties
Pan, Long; Adams, Kristie M.; Hernandez, Hayden E.; Wang, Xiaotai; Zheng, Chong; Hattori, Yoshiyuki; Kaneko, Katsumi
Journal of the American Chemical Society

The reactions of Ln(NO3)3 (Ln = La, Er) with 1,4-phenylendiacetic acid (H2PDA) under hydrothermal conditions produce isostructural lanthanide coordination polymers with the empirical formula [Ln2(PDA)3(H2O)].2H2O. Uncontrolled massive release of the primary greenhouse gas carbon dioxide (CO2) into atm. from anthropogenic activities poses a big threat and adversely affects our global climate and natural environment.  One promising approach to mitigate CO2 emission is carbon capture and storage (CCS), in which ideal adsorbent materials with high storage capacity and excellent adsorption selectivity over other gases are urgently needed.  For practical applications in CO2 capture from flue gas of power plants, the biggest single contributor of anthropogenic CO2 emission, the adsorbent materials must also be chem. stable, be easy to regenerate with minimal energy input, and be easily synthesized with low capital cost.  Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), highly cryst. porous materials constructed by metal ions and org. ligands, have emerged as a class of excellent adsorbent materials for carbon capture.  Great progress in MOF materials for CO2 capture has been made in the past and reviewed accordingly, but new discoveries are constantly being made as the field quickly grows.  In this paper, we provide a short review on the most recent advances in using MOFs for CO2 adsorption, storage, and sepn. that are directly related to CO2 capture. A review.  Adsorptive sepn. is very important in industry.  Generally, the process uses porous solid materials such as zeolites, activated carbons, or silica gels as adsorbents. Assembly of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) based on indium-trimer building blocks: a porous MOF with soc topology and high hydrogen storage
Liu, Yunling; Eubank, Jarrod F.; Cairns, Amy J.; Eckert, Juergen; Kravtsov, Victor Ch.; Luebke, Ryan; Eddaoudi, Mohamed

The synthesis and structure of two MOFs based on oxo-bridged trinuclear indium carboxylate clusters are reported.  The one MOF has a cubic structure with a CaB6 topol. and the other with an unprecedented soc topol. (soc = square-octahedron).  The results obtained indicate that MOFs possessing the characteristics of these two MOFs, combined with the modularity of their construction which allows higher surface areas to be obtained, will permit the attainment of the US DOE target for H2 uptake.
